column2: Richard Berry was a connection of Lincoln; his wife was a Shipley.]
column3: Richard Berry was a connection of Lincoln; his wife was a Shipley.]

column2: [Relocated Footnote (2): There is still living (1886) near Knob Creek in Kentucky, at the age of eighty, a man who claims to have known Abraham Lincoln in his childhood--Austin Gollaher.
column3: [Relocated Footnote (two): There is still living (eighteen eighty six) near Knob Creek in Kentucky, at the age of eighty, a man who claims to have known Abraham Lincoln in his childhood-Austin Gollaher.

column2: He says he used to play with Abe Lincoln in the shavings of his father's carpenter shop. He tells a story which, if accurate, entitles him to the civic crown which the Romans used to give to one who saved the life of a citizen. When Gollaher was eleven and Lincoln eight the two boys were in the woods in pursuit of partridges; in trying to "coon" across Knob Creek on a log, Lincoln fell in and Gollaher fished him out with a sycamore branch--a service to the Republic, the value of which it would be difficult to compute.]
column3: He says he used to play with Abe Lincoln in the shavings of his father's carpenter shop. He tells a story which, if accurate, entitles him to the civic crown which the romans used to give to one who saved the life of a citizen. column2: CHAPTER II

column2: INDIANA
column3: INDIANA

column2: [Sidenote: 1818.]
column3: [Sidenote: eighteen eighteen.]

column2: By the time the boy Abraham had attained his seventh year, the social condition of Kentucky had changed considerably from the early pioneer days.
column3: By the time the boy Abraham had attained his seventh year, the social condition of Kentucky had changed considerably from the early pioneer days.

column2: Life had assumed a more settled and orderly course.
column3: Life had assumed a more settled and orderly course.

column2: The old barbarous equality of the earlier time was gone; a difference of classes began to be seen.
column3: The old barbarous equality of the earlier time was gone; a difference of classes began to be seen.

column2: Those who held slaves assumed a distinct social superiority over those who did not.
column3: Those who held slaves assumed a distinct social superiority over those who did not.

column2: Thomas Lincoln, concluding that Kentucky was no country for a poor man, determined to seek his fortune in Indiana.
column3: Thomas Lincoln, concluding that Kentucky was no country for a poor man, determined to seek his fortune in Indiana.

column2: He had heard of rich and unoccupied lands in Perry County in that State, and thither he determined to go.
column3: He had heard of rich and unoccupied lands in Perry County in that State, and thither he determined to go.

column2: He built a rude raft, loaded it with his kit of tools and four hundred gallons of whisky, and trusted his fortunes to the winding water-courses.
column3: He built a rude raft, loaded it with his kit of tools and four hundred gallons of whisky, and trusted his fortunes to the winding water courses.

column2: He met with only one accident on his way: his raft capsized in the Ohio River, but he fished up his kit of tools and most of the ardent spirits, and arrived safely at the place of a settler named Posey, with whom he left his odd invoice of household goods for the wilderness, while he started on foot to look for a home in the dense forest.
column3: He met with only one accident on his way: his raft capsized in the Ohio River, but he fished up his kit of tools and most of the ardent spirits, and arrived safely at the place of a settler named Posey, with whom he left his odd invoice of household goods for the wilderness, while he started on foot to look for a home in the dense forest.

column2: He selected a spot which pleased him in his first day's journey.
column3: He selected a spot which pleased him in his first day's journey.

column2: He then walked back to Knob Creek and brought his family on to their new home.
column3: He then walked back to Knob Creek and brought his family on to their new home.

column2: No humbler cavalcade ever invaded the Indiana timber.
column3: No humbler cavalcade ever invaded the Indiana timber.

column2: Besides his wife and two children, his earthly possessions were of the slightest, for the backs of two borrowed horses sufficed for the load.
column3: Besides his wife and two children, his earthly possessions were of the slightest, for the backs of two borrowed horses sufficed for the load.

column2: Insufficient bedding and clothing, a few pans and kettles, were their sole movable wealth.
column3: Insufficient bedding and clothing, a few pans and kettles, were their sole movable wealth.

column2: They relied on Lincoln's kit of tools for their furniture, and on his rifle for their food.
column3: They relied on Lincoln's kit of tools for their furniture, and on his rifle for their food.

column2: At Posey's they hired a wagon and literally hewed a path through the wilderness to their new habitation near Little Pigeon Creek, a mile and a half east of Gentryville, in a rich and fertile forest country.
column3: At Posey's they hired a wagon and literally hewed a path through the wilderness to their new habitation near Little Pigeon Creek, a mile and a half east of Gentryville, in a rich and fertile forest country.

column2: Thomas Lincoln, with the assistance of his wife and children, built a temporary shelter of the sort called in the frontier language "a half- faced camp"; merely a shed of poles, which defended the inmates on three sides from foul weather, but left them open to its inclemency in front.
column3: Thomas Lincoln, with the assistance of his wife and children, built a temporary shelter of the sort called in the frontier language "a half faced camp"; merely a shed of poles, which defended the inmates on three sides from foul weather, but left them open to its inclemency in front.

column2: For a whole year his family lived in this wretched fold, while he was clearing a little patch of ground for planting corn, and building a rough cabin for a permanent residence.
column3: For a whole year his family lived in this wretched fold, while he was clearing a little patch of ground for planting corn, and building a rough cabin for a permanent residence.

column2: They moved into the latter before it was half completed; for by this time the Sparrows had followed the Lincolns from Kentucky, and the half-faced camp was given up to them.
column3: They moved into the latter before it was half completed; for by this time the Sparrows had followed the Lincolns from Kentucky, and the half faced camp was given up to them.

column2: But the rude cabin seemed so spacious and comfortable after the squalor of "the camp," that Thomas Lincoln did no further work on it for a long time.
column3: But the rude cabin seemed so spacious and comfortable after the squalor of "the camp," that Thomas Lincoln did no further work on it for a long time.

column2: He left it for a year or two without doors, or windows, or floor.
column3: He left it for a year or two without doors, or windows, or floor.

column2: The battle for existence allowed him no time for such superfluities.
column3: The battle for existence allowed him no time for such superfluities.

column2: He raised enough corn to support life; the dense forest around him abounded in every form of feathered game; a little way from his cabin an open glade was full of deer-licks, and an hour or two of idle waiting was generally rewarded by a shot at a fine deer, which would furnish meat for a week, and material for breeches and shoes.
column3: He raised enough corn to support life; the dense forest around him abounded in every form of feathered game; a little way from his cabin an open glade was full of deer licks, and an hour or two of idle waiting was generally rewarded by a shot at a fine deer, which would furnish meat for a week, and material for breeches and shoes.

column2: His cabin was like that of other pioneers.
column3: His cabin was like that of other pioneers.

column2: A few three-legged stools; a bedstead made of poles stuck between the logs in the angle of the cabin, the outside corner supported by a crotched stick driven into the ground; the table, a huge hewed log standing on four legs; a pot, kettle, and skillet, and a few tin and pewter dishes were all the furniture.
column3: A few three legged stools; a bedstead made of poles stuck between the logs in the angle of the cabin, the outside corner supported by a crotched stick driven into the ground; the table, a huge hewed log standing on four legs; a pot, kettle, and skillet, and a few tin and pewter dishes were all the furniture.

column2: The boy Abraham climbed at night to his bed of leaves in the loft, by a ladder of wooden pins driven into the logs.
column3: The boy Abraham climbed at night to his bed of leaves in the loft, by a ladder of wooden pins driven into the logs.

column2: This life has been vaunted by poets and romancers as a happy and healthful one.
column3: This life has been vaunted by poets and romancers as a happy and healthful one.

column2: Even Dennis Hanks, speaking of his youthful days when his only home was the half-faced camp, says, "I tell you, Billy, I enjoyed myself better then than I ever have since." But we may distrust the reminiscences of old settlers, who see their youth in the flattering light of distance.
column3: Even Dennis Hanks, speaking of his youthful days when his only home was the half faced camp, says, "I tell you, Billy, I enjoyed myself better then than I ever have since." But we may distrust the reminiscences of old settlers, who see their youth in the flattering light of distance.

column2: The life was neither enjoyable nor wholesome.
column3: The life was neither enjoyable nor wholesome.

column2: The rank woods were full of malaria, and singular epidemics from time to time ravaged the settlements.
column3: The rank woods were full of malaria, and singular epidemics from time to time ravaged the settlements.

column2: In the autumn of 1818 the little community of Pigeon Creek was almost exterminated by a frightful pestilence called the milk-sickness, or, in the dialect of the country, "the milk-sick." It is a mysterious disease which has been the theme of endless wrangling among Western physicians, and the difficulty of ascertaining anything about it has been greatly increased by the local sensitiveness which forbids any one to admit that any well-defined case has ever been seen in his neighborhood, "although just over the creek (or in the next county) they have had it bad." It seems to have been a malignant form of fever--attributed variously to malaria and to the eating of poisonous herbs by the cattle--attacking cattle as well as human beings, attended with violent retching and a burning sensation in the stomach, often terminating fatally on the third day.
column3: In the autumn of eighteen eighteen the little community of Pigeon Creek was almost exterminated by a frightful pestilence called the milk sickness, or, in the dialect of the country, "the milk sick." It is a mysterious disease which has been the theme of endless wrangling among Western physicians, and the difficulty of ascertaining anything about it has been greatly increased by the local sensitiveness which forbids any one to admit that any well defined case has ever been seen in his neighborhood, "although just over the creek (or in the next county) they have had it bad." It seems to have been a malignant form of fever-attributed variously to malaria and to the eating of poisonous herbs by the cattle-attacking cattle as well as human beings, attended with violent retching and a burning sensation in the stomach, often terminating fatally on the third day.

column2: In many cases those who apparently recovered lingered for years with health seriously impaired.
column3: In many cases those who apparently recovered lingered for years with health seriously impaired.

column2: Among the Pioneers of Pigeon Creek, so ill-fed, ill-housed, and uncared for, there was little prospect of recovery from such a grave disorder.
column3: Among the Pioneers of Pigeon Creek, so ill fed, ill housed, and uncared for, there was little prospect of recovery from such a grave disorder.

column2: The Sparrows, husband and wife, died early in October, and Nancy Hanks Lincoln followed them after an interval of a few days. Thomas Lincoln made the coffins for his dead "out of green lumber cut with a whipsaw," and they were all buried, with scant ceremony, in a little clearing of the forest.
column3: The Sparrows, husband and wife, died early in October, and Nancy Hanks Lincoln followed them after an interval of a few days. Thomas Lincoln made the coffins for his dead "out of green lumber cut with a whipsaw," and they were all buried, with scant ceremony, in a little clearing of the forest.

column2: It is related of young Abraham, that he sorrowed most of all that his mother should have been laid away with such maimed rites, and that he contrived several months later to have a wandering preacher named David Elkin brought to the settlement, to deliver a funeral sermon over her grave, already white with the early winter snows.
column3: It is related of young Abraham, that he sorrowed most of all that his mother should have been laid away with such maimed rites, and that he contrived several months later to have a wandering preacher named David Elkin brought to the settlement, to deliver a funeral sermon over her grave, already white with the early winter snows.

column2: [Footnote: A stone has been placed over the site of the grave "by P. E. Studebaker, of South Bend, Indiana." The stone bears the following inscription: "Nancy Hanks Lincoln, mother of President Lincoln, died October 5th, A. D. 1818, aged 35 years.
column3: [Footnote: A stone has been placed over the site of the grave "by p e Studebaker, of south bend indiana." The stone bears the following inscription: "Nancy Hanks Lincoln, mother of President Lincoln, died october fifth, a d eighteen eighteen, aged thirty five years.

column2: Erected by a friend of her martyred son, 1879."]
column3: Erected by a friend of her martyred son, eighteen seventy nine."]

column2: This was the dreariest winter of his life, for before the next December came his father had brought from Kentucky a new wife, who was to change the lot of all the desolate little family very much for the better.
column3: This was the dreariest winter of his life, for before the next December came his father had brought from Kentucky a new wife, who was to change the lot of all the desolate little family very much for the better.

column2: Sarah Bush had been an acquaintance of Thomas Lincoln before his first marriage; she had, it is said, rejected him to marry one Johnston, the jailer at Elizabethtown, who had died, leaving her with three children, a boy and two girls.
column3: Sarah Bush had been an acquaintance of Thomas Lincoln before his first marriage; she had, it is said, rejected him to marry one Johnston, the jailer at Elizabethtown, who had died, leaving her with three children, a boy and two girls.

column2: When Lincoln's widowhood had lasted a year, he went down to Elizabethtown to begin again the wooing broken off so many years before.
column3: When Lincoln's widowhood had lasted a year, he went down to Elizabethtown to begin again the wooing broken off so many years before.

column2: He wasted no time in preliminaries, but promptly made his wishes known, and the next morning they were married.
column3: He wasted no time in preliminaries, but promptly made his wishes known, and the next morning they were married.

column2: It was growing late in the autumn, and the pioneer probably dreaded another lonely winter on Pigeon Creek.
column3: It was growing late in the autumn, and the pioneer probably dreaded another lonely winter on Pigeon Creek.

column2: Mrs. Johnston was not altogether portionless.
column3: mrs Johnston was not altogether portionless.

column2: She had a store of household goods which filled a four-horse wagon borrowed of Ralph Grume, Thomas Lincoln's brother-in-law, to transport the bride to Indiana.
column3: She had a store of household goods which filled a four horse wagon borrowed of Ralph Grume, Thomas Lincoln's brother in law, to transport the bride to Indiana.

column2: It took little time for this energetic and honest Christian woman to make her influence felt, even in those discouraging surroundings, and Thomas Lincoln and the children were the better for her coming all the rest of their lives.
column3: It took little time for this energetic and honest Christian woman to make her influence felt, even in those discouraging surroundings, and Thomas Lincoln and the children were the better for her coming all the rest of their lives.

column2: The lack of doors and floors was at once corrected.
column3: The lack of doors and floors was at once corrected.

column2: Her honest pride inspired her husband to greater thrift and industry.
column3: Her honest pride inspired her husband to greater thrift and industry.

column2: The goods she brought with her compelled some effort at harmony in the other fittings of the house.
column3: The goods she brought with her compelled some effort at harmony in the other fittings of the house.

column2: She dressed the children in warmer clothing and put them to sleep in comfortable beds.
column3: She dressed the children in warmer clothing and put them to sleep in comfortable beds.

column2: With this slight addition to their resources the family were much improved in appearance, behavior, and self-respect.
column3: With this slight addition to their resources the family were much improved in appearance, behavior, and self respect.

column2: [Illustration: SARAH BUSH LINCOLN AT THE AGE OF SEVENTY-SIX.]
column3: [Illustration: SARAH BUSH LINCOLN AT THE AGE OF SEVENTY SIX.]

column2: Thomas Lincoln joined the Baptist church at Little Pigeon in 1823; his oldest child, Sarah, followed his example three years later.
column3: Thomas Lincoln joined the Baptist church at Little Pigeon in eighteen twenty three; his oldest child, Sarah, followed his example three years later.

column2: They were known as active and consistent members of that communion.
column3: They were known as active and consistent members of that communion.

column2: Lincoln was himself a good carpenter when he chose to work at his trade; a walnut table made by him is still preserved as part of the furniture of the church to which he belonged.
column3: Lincoln was himself a good carpenter when he chose to work at his trade; a walnut table made by him is still preserved as part of the furniture of the church to which he belonged.

column2: T.V. Robertson, pastor of the Little Pigeon Baptist church.]
column3: t v Robertson, pastor of the Little Pigeon Baptist church.]

column2: Such a woman as Sarah Bush could not be careless of so important a matter as the education of her children, and they made the best use of the scanty opportunities the neighborhood afforded.
column3: Such a woman as Sarah Bush could not be careless of so important a matter as the education of her children, and they made the best use of the scanty opportunities the neighborhood afforded.

column2: It was a wild region, writes Mr. Lincoln, in one of those rare bits of autobiography which he left behind him, "with many bears and other wild animals still in the woods.
column3: It was a wild region, writes mr Lincoln, in one of those rare bits of autobiography which he left behind him, "with many bears and other wild animals still in the woods.

column2: There were some schools so-called, but no qualification was ever required of a teacher beyond 'readin', writin', and cipherin' to the Rule of Three.' If a straggler supposed to understand Latin happened to sojourn in the neighborhood, he was looked upon as a wizard.
column3: There were some schools so-called, but no qualification was ever required of a teacher beyond 'readin', writin', and cipherin' to the Rule of Three.' If a straggler supposed to understand Latin happened to sojourn in the neighborhood, he was looked upon as a wizard.

column2: There was absolutely nothing to excite ambition for education." But in the case of this ungainly boy there was no necessity of any external incentive.
column3: There was absolutely nothing to excite ambition for education." But in the case of this ungainly boy there was no necessity of any external incentive.

column2: A thirst for knowledge as a means of rising in the world was innate in him.
column3: A thirst for knowledge as a means of rising in the world was innate in him.

column2: It had nothing to do with that love of science for its own sake which has been so often seen in lowly savants, who have sacrificed their lives to the pure desire of knowing the works of God.
column3: It had nothing to do with that love of science for its own sake which has been so often seen in lowly savants, who have sacrificed their lives to the pure desire of knowing the works of God.

column2: All the little learning he ever acquired he seized as a tool to better his condition.
column3: All the little learning he ever acquired he seized as a tool to better his condition.

column2: He learned his letters that he might read books and see how men in the great world outside of his woods had borne themselves in the fight for which he longed.
column3: He learned his letters that he might read books and see how men in the great world outside of his woods had borne themselves in the fight for which he longed.

column2: He learned to write, first, that he might have an accomplishment his playmates had not; then that he might help his elders by writing their letters, and enjoy the feeling of usefulness which this gave him; and finally that he might copy what struck him in his reading and thus make it his own for future use.
column3: He learned to write, first, that he might have an accomplishment his playmates had not; then that he might help his elders by writing their letters, and enjoy the feeling of usefulness which this gave him; and finally that he might copy what struck him in his reading and thus make it his own for future use.

column2: He learned to cipher certainly from no love of mathematics, but because it might come in play in some more congenial business than the farm-work which bounded the horizon of his contemporaries.
column3: He learned to cipher certainly from no love of mathematics, but because it might come in play in some more congenial business than the farm work which bounded the horizon of his contemporaries.

column2: Had it not been for that interior spur which kept his clear spirit at its task, his schools could have done little for him; for, counting his attendance under Riney and Hazel in Kentucky, and under Dorsey, Crawford, and Swaney in Indiana, it amounted to less than a year in all.
column3: Had it not been for that interior spur which kept his clear spirit at its task, his schools could have done little for him; for, counting his attendance under Riney and Hazel in Kentucky, and under Dorsey, Crawford, and Swaney in Indiana, it amounted to less than a year in all.

column2: The schools were much alike.
column3: The schools were much alike.

column2: They were held in deserted cabins of round logs, with earthen floors, and small holes for windows, sometimes illuminated by as much light as could penetrate through panes of paper greased with lard.
column3: They were held in deserted cabins of round logs, with earthen floors, and small holes for windows, sometimes illuminated by as much light as could penetrate through panes of paper greased with lard.

column2: The teachers were usually in keeping with their primitive surroundings. The profession offered no rewards sufficient to attract men of education or capacity.
column3: The teachers were usually in keeping with their primitive surroundings. The profession offered no rewards sufficient to attract men of education or capacity.

column2: After a few months of desultory instruction young Abraham knew all that these vagrant literati could teach him. His last school-days were passed with one Swaney in 1826, who taught at a distance of four and a half miles from the Lincoln cabin.
column3: After a few months of desultory instruction young Abraham knew all that these vagrant literati could teach him. His last school days were passed with one Swaney in eighteen twenty six, who taught at a distance of four and a half miles from the Lincoln cabin.

column2: The nine miles of walking doubtless seemed to Thomas Lincoln a waste of time, and the lad was put at steady work and saw no more of school.
column3: The nine miles of walking doubtless seemed to Thomas Lincoln a waste of time, and the lad was put at steady work and saw no more of school.

column2: But it is questionable whether he lost anything by being deprived of the ministrations of the backwoods dominies.
column3: But it is questionable whether he lost anything by being deprived of the ministrations of the backwoods dominies.

column2: When his tasks ended, his studies became the chief pleasure of his life.
column3: When his tasks ended, his studies became the chief pleasure of his life.

column2: In all the intervals of his work--in which he never took delight, knowing well enough that he was born for something better than that--he read, wrote, and ciphered incessantly.
column3: In all the intervals of his work-in which he never took delight, knowing well enough that he was born for something better than that-he read, wrote, and ciphered incessantly.

column2: His reading was naturally limited by his opportunities, for books were among the rarest of luxuries in that region and time. But he read everything he could lay his hands upon, and he was certainly fortunate in the few books of which he became the possessor. It would hardly be possible to select a better handful of classics for a youth in his circumstances than the few volumes he turned with a nightly and daily hand--the Bible, "Aesop's Fables," "Robinson Crusoe," "The Pilgrim's Progress," a history of the United States, and Weem's "Life of Washington." These were the best, and these he read over and over till he knew them almost by heart.
column3: His reading was naturally limited by his opportunities, for books were among the rarest of luxuries in that region and time. But he read everything he could lay his hands upon, and he was certainly fortunate in the few books of which he became the possessor. It would hardly be possible to select a better handful of classics for a youth in his circumstances than the few volumes he turned with a nightly and daily hand-the Bible, "Aesop's Fables," "Robinson Crusoe," "The Pilgrim's Progress," a history of the United States, and Weem's "Life of Washington." These were the best, and these he read over and over till he knew them almost by heart.

column2: But his voracity for anything printed was insatiable.
column3: But his voracity for anything printed was insatiable.

column2: He would sit in the twilight and read a dictionary as long as he could see.
column3: He would sit in the twilight and read a dictionary as long as he could see.

column2: He used to go to David Turnham's, the town constable, and devour the "Revised Statutes of Indiana," as boys in our day do the "Three Guardsmen." Of the books he did not own he took voluminous notes, filling his copy-book with choice extracts, and poring over them until they were fixed in his memory.
column3: He used to go to David Turnham's, the town constable, and devour the "Revised Statutes of Indiana," as boys in our day do the "Three Guardsmen." Of the books he did not own he took voluminous notes, filling his copy book with choice extracts, and poring over them until they were fixed in his memory.

column2: He could not afford to waste paper upon his original compositions.
column3: He could not afford to waste paper upon his original compositions.

column2: He would sit by the fire at night and cover the wooden shovel with essays and arithmetical exercises, which he would shave off and then begin again. It is touching to think of this great-spirited child, battling year after year against his evil star, wasting his ingenuity upon devices and makeshifts, his high intelligence starving for want of the simple appliances of education that are now offered gratis to the poorest and most indifferent.
column3: He would sit by the fire at night and cover the wooden shovel with essays and arithmetical exercises, which he would shave off and then begin again. It is touching to think of this great spirited child, battling year after year against his evil star, wasting his ingenuity upon devices and makeshifts, his high intelligence starving for want of the simple appliances of education that are now offered gratis to the poorest and most indifferent.

column2: He did a man's work from the time he left school; his strength and stature were already far beyond those of ordinary men.
column3: He did a man's work from the time he left school; his strength and stature were already far beyond those of ordinary men.

column2: He wrought his appointed tasks ungrudgingly, though without enthusiasm; but when his employer's day was over, his own began.
column3: He wrought his appointed tasks ungrudgingly, though without enthusiasm; but when his employer's day was over, his own began.

column2: John Hanks says: "When Abe and I returned to the house from work he would go to the cupboard, snatch a piece of corn-bread, take down a book, sit down, cock his legs up as high as his head, and read." The picture may be lacking in grace, but its truthfulness is beyond question.
column3: john Hanks says: "When Abe and I returned to the house from work he would go to the cupboard, snatch a piece of corn bread, take down a book, sit down, cock his legs up as high as his head, and read." The picture may be lacking in grace, but its truthfulness is beyond question.

column2: The habit remained with him always.
column3: The habit remained with him always.

column2: Some of his greatest work in later years was done in this grotesque Western fashion,--"sitting on his shoulder-blades."
column3: Some of his greatest work in later years was done in this grotesque Western fashion,--"sitting on his shoulder blades."

column3: [Sidenote: w h Lamou "Life of Lincoln," p. thirty seven.]

column3: [Sidenote: Damon, p. eighty.]

column2: Otherwise his life at this time differed little from that of ordinary farm-hands.
column3: Otherwise his life at this time differed little from that of ordinary farm hands.

column2: His great strength and intelligence made him a valuable laborer, and his unfailing good temper and flow of rude rustic wit rendered him the most agreeable of comrades.
column3: His great strength and intelligence made him a valuable laborer, and his unfailing good temper and flow of rude rustic wit rendered him the most agreeable of comrades.

column2: He was always ready with some kindly act or word for others.
column3: He was always ready with some kindly act or word for others.

column2: Once he saved the life of the town drunkard, whom he found freezing by the roadside, by carrying him in his strong arms to the tavern, and working over him until he revived. It is a curious fact that this act of common humanity was regarded as something remarkable in the neighborhood; the grateful sot himself always said "it was mighty clever of Abe to tote me so far that cold night." It was also considered an eccentricity that he hated and preached against cruelty to animals.
column3: Once he saved the life of the town drunkard, whom he found freezing by the roadside, by carrying him in his strong arms to the tavern, and working over him until he revived. It is a curious fact that this act of common humanity was regarded as something remarkable in the neighborhood; the grateful sot himself always said "it was mighty clever of Abe to tote me so far that cold night." It was also considered an eccentricity that he hated and preached against cruelty to animals.

column2: Some of his comrades remember still his bursts of righteous wrath, when a boy, against the wanton murder of turtles and other creatures.
column3: Some of his comrades remember still his bursts of righteous wrath, when a boy, against the wanton murder of turtles and other creatures.

column2: He was evidently of better and finer clay than his fellows, even in those wild and ignorant days.
column3: He was evidently of better and finer clay than his fellows, even in those wild and ignorant days.

column2: At home he was the life of the singularly assorted household, which consisted, besides his parents and himself, of his own sister, Mrs. Lincoln's two girls and boy, Dennis Hanks, the legacy of the dying Sparrow family, and John Hanks (son of the carpenter Joseph with whom Thomas Lincoln learned his trade), who came from Kentucky several years after the others.

column2: It was probably as much the inexhaustible good nature and kindly helpfulness of young Abraham which kept the peace among all these heterogeneous elements, effervescing with youth and confined in a one-roomed cabin, as it was the Christian sweetness and firmness of the woman of the house.

column2: It was a happy and united household: brothers and sisters and cousins living peacefully under the gentle rule of the good stepmother, but all acknowledging from a very early period the supremacy in goodness and cleverness of their big brother Abraham.
column3: It was a happy and united household: brothers and sisters and cousins living peacefully under the gentle rule of the good stepmother, but all acknowledging from a very early period the supremacy in goodness and cleverness of their big brother Abraham.

column2: Mrs. Lincoln, not long before her death, gave striking testimony of his winning and loyal character.

column2: She said to Mr. Herndon: "I can say, what scarcely one mother in a thousand can say, Abe never gave me a cross word or look, and never refused in fact or appearance to do anything I asked him.

column2: His mind and mine--what little I had--seemed to run together....

column2: I had a son John, who was raised with Abe.

column2: Both were good boys, but I must say, both now being dead, that Abe was the best boy I ever saw or expect to see." Such were the beginnings of this remarkable career, sacred as we see from childhood, to duty and to human kindliness.

column2: He was merely a good boy, with sufficient wickedness to prove his humanity.

column2: One of his employers, undazzled by recent history, faithfully remembers that young Abe liked his dinner and his pay better than his work: there is surely nothing alien to ordinary mortality in this.

column3: His budding talents as a writer were not always used discreetly.

column2: Before we close our sketch of this period of Lincoln's life, it may not be amiss to glance for a moment at the state of society among the people with whom his lot was cast in these important years.

column2: In most respects there had been little moral or material improvement since the early settlement of the country.

column2: Their houses were usually of one room, built of round logs with the bark on.
column3: Their houses were usually of one room, built of round logs with the bark on.

column2: Their dress was still mostly of tanned deer-hide, a material to the last degree uncomfortable when the wearer was caught in a shower.

column2: Their shoes were of the same, and a good Western authority calls a wet moccasin "a decent way of going barefoot." column3: But for a good while it was only the women who indulged in these novelties.

column2: There was little public worship.

column2: Occasionally an itinerant preacher visited a county, and the settlers for miles around would go nearly in mass to the meeting.
column3: Occasionally an itinerant preacher visited a county, and the settlers for miles around would go nearly in mass to the meeting.

column2: If a man was possessed of a wagon, the family rode luxuriously; but as a rule the men walked and the women went on horseback with the little children in their arms.

column2: It was considered no violation of the sanctities of the occasion to carry a rifle and take advantage of any game which might be stirring during the long walk.
column3: It was considered no violation of the sanctities of the occasion to carry a rifle and take advantage of any game which might be stirring during the long walk.

column2: Arriving at the place of meeting, which was some log cabin if the weather was foul, or the shade of a tree if it was fair, the assembled worshipers threw their provisions into a common store and picnicked in neighborly companionship.
column3: Arriving at the place of meeting, which was some log cabin if the weather was foul, or the shade of a tree if it was fair, the assembled worshipers threw their provisions into a common store and picnicked in neighborly companionship.

column2: The preacher would then take off his coat, and go at his work with an energy unknown to our days.
column3: The preacher would then take off his coat, and go at his work with an energy unknown to our days.

column2: There were few other social meetings.
column3: There were few other social meetings.

column2: Men came together for "raisings," where a house was built in a day; for "log-rollings," where tons of excellent timber were piled together and wastefully burned; for wolf-hunts, where a tall pole was erected in the midst of a prairie or clearing, and a great circle of hunters formed around it, sometimes of miles in diameter, which, gradually contracting with shouts and yells, drove all the game in the woods together at the pole for slaughter; and for horse-races, which bore little resemblance to those magnificent exhibitions which are the boast of Kentucky at this time.
column3: Men came together for "raisings," where a house was built in a day; for "log rollings," where tons of excellent timber were piled together and wastefully burned; for wolf hunts, where a tall pole was erected in the midst of a prairie or clearing, and a great circle of hunters formed around it, sometimes of miles in diameter, which, gradually contracting with shouts and yells, drove all the game in the woods together at the pole for slaughter; and for horse races, which bore little resemblance to those magnificent exhibitions which are the boast of Kentucky at this time.

column2: In these affairs the women naturally took no part; but weddings, which were entertainments scarcely less rude and boisterous, were their own peculiar province.
column3: In these affairs the women naturally took no part; but weddings, which were entertainments scarcely less rude and boisterous, were their own peculiar province.

column2: These festivities lasted rarely less than twenty-four hours.
column3: These festivities lasted rarely less than twenty four hours.

column2: The guests assembled in the morning.
column3: The guests assembled in the morning.

column2: There was a race for the whisky bottle; a midday dinner; an afternoon of rough games and outrageous practical jokes; a supper and dance at night, interrupted by the successive withdrawals of the bride and of the groom, attended with ceremonies and jests of more than Rabelaisian crudeness; and a noisy dispersal next day.

column2: The one point at which they instinctively clung to civilization was their regard for law and reverence for courts of justice.
column3: The one point at which they instinctively clung to civilization was their regard for law and reverence for courts of justice.

column2: Yet these were of the simplest character and totally devoid of any adventitious accessories.
column3: Yet these were of the simplest character and totally devoid of any adventitious accessories.

column2: An early jurist of the country writes: "I was Circuit Prosecuting Attorney at the time of the trials at the falls of Fall Creek, where Pendleton now stands.
column3: An early jurist of the country writes: "I was Circuit Prosecuting Attorney at the time of the trials at the falls of Fall Creek, where Pendleton now stands.

column2: Four of the prisoners were convicted of murder, and three of them hung, for killing Indians.
column3: Four of the prisoners were convicted of murder, and three of them hung, for killing Indians.

column2: The court was held in a double log cabin, the grand jury sat upon a log in the woods, and the foreman signed the bills of indictment, which I had prepared, upon his knee; there was not a petit juror that had shoes on; all wore moccasins, and were belted around the waist, and carried side-knives used by the hunters." Yet amidst all this apparent savagery we see justice was done, and the law vindicated even against the bitterest prejudices of these pioneer jurymen.

column2: They were full of strange superstitions.

column2: The belief in witchcraft had long ago passed away with the smoke of the fagots from old and New England, but it survived far into this century in Kentucky and the lower halves of Indiana and Illinois--touched with a peculiar tinge of African magic.

column2: The pioneers believed in it for good and evil.
column3: The pioneers believed in it for good and evil.

column2: Their veterinary practice was mostly by charms and incantations; and when a person believed himself bewitched, a shot at the image of the witch with a bullet melted out of a half-dollar was the favorite curative agency.
column3: Their veterinary practice was mostly by charms and incantations; and when a person believed himself bewitched, a shot at the image of the witch with a bullet melted out of a half dollar was the favorite curative agency.

column2: Luck was an active divinity in their apprehension, powerful for blessing or bane, announced by homely signs, to be placated by quaint ceremonies.
column3: Luck was an active divinity in their apprehension, powerful for blessing or bane, announced by homely signs, to be placated by quaint ceremonies.

column2: A dog crossing the hunter's path spoiled his day, unless he instantly hooked his little fingers together, and pulled till the animal disappeared.
column3: A dog crossing the hunter's path spoiled his day, unless he instantly hooked his little fingers together, and pulled till the animal disappeared.

column2: They were familiar with the ever- recurring mystification of the witch-hazel, or divining-rod; and the "cure by faith" was as well known to them as it has since become in a more sophisticated state of society.

column2: The commonest occurrences were heralds of death and doom.
column3: The commonest occurrences were heralds of death and doom.

column2: A bird lighting in a window, a dog baying at certain hours, the cough of a horse in the direction of a child, the sight, or worse still, the touch of a dead snake, heralded domestic woe.
column3: A bird lighting in a window, a dog baying at certain hours, the cough of a horse in the direction of a child, the sight, or worse still, the touch of a dead snake, heralded domestic woe.

column2: A wagon driving past the house with a load of baskets was a warning of atmospheric disturbance.
column3: A wagon driving past the house with a load of baskets was a warning of atmospheric disturbance.

column2: A vague and ignorant astronomy governed their plantings and sowings, the breeding of their cattle, and all farm-work.
column3: A vague and ignorant astronomy governed their plantings and sowings, the breeding of their cattle, and all farm work.

column2: They must fell trees for fence-rails before noon, and in the waxing of the moon.
column3: They must fell trees for fence rails before noon, and in the waxing of the moon.

column2: Fences built when there was no moon would give way; but that was the proper season for planting potatoes and other vegetables whose fruit grows underground; those which bore their product in the air must be planted when the moon shone.
column3: Fences built when there was no moon would give way; but that was the proper season for planting potatoes and other vegetables whose fruit grows underground; those which bore their product in the air must be planted when the moon shone.

column3: The magical power of the moon was wide in its influence; it extended to the most minute details of life.

column3: His mind was slow in acquisition, and his powers of reasoning and rhetoric improved constantly to the end of his life, at a rate of progress marvelously regular and sustained.

column3: He attained his full growth, six feet and four inches, two years before he came of age.

column3: One aged man says that he has seen him pick up and carry away a chicken house weighing six hundred pounds.

column2: One of his employers says, "He could sink an axe deeper into wood than any man I ever saw." column2: The young merchants had tied up for the night and were asleep in the cabin, when they were aroused by shuffling footsteps, which proved to be a gang of marauding negroes, coming to rob the boat.

column2: Abraham instantly attacked them with a club, knocked several overboard and put the rest to flight; flushed with battle, he and Allen Gentry carried the war into the enemy's country, and pursued the retreating Africans some distance in the darkness. They then returned to the boat, bleeding but victorious, and hastily swung into the stream and floated down the river till daylight. Lincoln's exertion in later years for the welfare of the African race showed that this nocturnal battle had not led him to any hasty and hostile generalizations.

column2: The next autumn, John Hanks, the steadiest and most trustworthy of his family, went to Illinois.

column2: Though an illiterate and rather dull man, he had a good deal of solidity of character and consequently some influence and consideration in the household.

column2: He settled in Macon County, and was so well pleased with the country, and especially with its admirable distribution into prairie and timber, that he sent repeated messages to his friends in Indiana to come out and join him. Thomas Lincoln was always ready to move.

column2: He had probably by this time despaired of ever owning any unencumbered real estate in Indiana, and the younger members of the family had little to bind them to the place where they saw nothing in the future but hard work and poor living. Thomas Lincoln handed over his farm to Mr. Gentry, sold his crop of corn and hogs, packed his household goods and those of his children and sons-in-law into a single wagon, drawn by two yoke of oxen, the combined wealth of himself and Dennis Hanks, and started for the new State.

column3: He had already selected a piece of ground for them a few miles from his own, and had the logs ready for their house.

column2: They numbered men enough to build without calling in their neighbors, and immediately put up a cabin on the north fork of the Sangamon River.

column2: The family thus housed and sheltered, one more bit of filial work remained for Abraham before assuming his virile independence.

column2: With the assistance of John Hanks he plowed fifteen acres, and split, from the tall walnut-trees of the primeval forest, enough rails to surround them with a fence.
column3: With the assistance of john Hanks he plowed fifteen acres, and split, from the tall walnut trees of the primeval forest, enough rails to surround them with a fence.

column2: Little did either dream, while engaged in this work, that the day would come when the appearance of John Hanks in a public meeting, with two of these rails on his shoulder, would electrify a State convention, and kindle throughout the country a contagious and passionate enthusiasm, whose results would reach to endless generations.
